benchmark_details.name: ChartGaze
benchmark_details.overview: ChartGaze is a new eye-tracking dataset that captures human gaze patterns during chart reasoning tasks, designed to improve attention alignment in Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) and enhance interpretability and accuracy of chart Question Answering (CQA).

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a dataset for improving attention alignment in LVLMs used for chart understanding, thereby enhancing model interpretability and accuracy.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The study focuses on Yes/No questions and relatively simple chart types, which may limit generalizability to more complex visualizations and open-ended questions.

data.source: Constructed from chart images sourced from ChartQA and VisText datasets, combined with human gaze data collected during chart reasoning tasks.
data.size: 4,638 attention maps from 1,620 unique chart images
data.annotation: Eye-tracking data captured using Tobii Pro Fusion for detailed human gaze mapping during the task.

methodology.calculation: Metrics calculated based on the alignment of model-derived attention maps with human gaze data and the percentage of questions answered correctly.
methodology.interpretation: Higher scores in CC and SIM indicate better alignment of model attention with human gaze and higher accuracy reflects improved understanding.
methodology.baseline_results: LVLMs fine-tuned with gaze-guided attention refinement improved accuracy by up to 2.56 percentage points over those trained with language loss alone.
methodology.validation: The dataset was validated through human annotation and gaze data quality controls including filtering for accuracy.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: Demographics of participants involved in the eye-tracking data collection were balanced across gender and academic fields.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: All collected gaze data were de-identified and securely stored on encrypted devices to protect participant privacy.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: Participants provided informed consent and were compensated for their participation.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.compliance_with_regulations: The study was reviewed and approved by the University of British Columbia behavioural research ethics board.
